Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effects of Atmospheric Aging on the Surface vs. Bulk Composition of Atmospheric Organic Aerosol
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division supports Professor Jesse H. Kroll of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the laboratory study of chemical differences between organic compounds present at the air-particle interface and those found within the bulk of the particles. New analytical techniques for the real-time measurement of the surface composition are being investigated and developed; these include combinations of soot particle aerosol mass spectrometry (SP-AMS, a laser-based technique for the rapid vaporization of particles containing black carbon or metal cores), tunable vacuum ultraviolet photoionization (VUV, a soft ionization technique), and direct analysis in real time (DART, a mass spectrometric technique for the measurement of material surfaces). These state-of-the-art techniques will then be used in environmental chamber studies, examining how the condensation of secondary species affect organic aerosol composition, with a focus on the extent and rate of mixing between various aerosol components.

This study is expected to provide new insights into the formation and evolution of atmospheric organic fine particles. The direct examination of chemical gradients and mixing within such particles will provide important constraints on their atmospheric behavior, reactivity, and fate, and ultimately on their role in global climate and human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic aerosol (OA) particles make up a large fraction of atmospheric fine particulate matter, and therefore can have important impacts on global climate and human health. However, because of the chemical complexity and reactivity of the organic species within the particles, they are challenging to accurately describe using atmospheric models. This laboratory project involved examination of a potentially important (and only recently appreciated) aspect of the atmospheric reactivity of organic particles, the differences between the chemistry at the surface of the particles and chemistry within the particle itself. There were two primary components to this work, the development of new mass spectrometric tools for the selective study of the composition at particle surfaces, and laboratory studies examining how oxidation chemistry may affect the particle surface and bulk differently. In the first category, this project led to the development and successful demonstration of soot particle-vacuum ultraviolet aerosol mass spectrometry (SP-VUV-AMS), in which particle are analyzed by vaporization by infrared light followed by ionization by vacuum ultraviolet light. This is a substantially “softer” technique than standard analysis techniques, affording more chemical information about the particle composition, including particles covered with thin coatings of organic species (allowing for the examination of surface chemistry only).

Laboratory studies focused on heterogeneous oxidation, the reaction of gas-phase oxidants (specifically the hydroxyl radical OH) with OA components. The SP-VUV-AMS technique was used to examine the oxidation of soot particles, specifically the organic species associated with the soot surface; this was found to be rapid compared to most previous oxidation studies. This effect was examined in greater detail in a second set of experiments that examined the role of thin coatings on heterogeneous oxidation chemistry. These studies focused on the oxidation of a liquid hydrocarbon (squalane, C30H62), first as pure particles and then as thin coatings on an unreactive “core”. It was found that the squalane within the coatings reacted far faster than that within the pure particles, due to their higher surface-area-to-volume ratios (and thus greater exposure to the gas-phase oxidants). Such work indicates that heterogeneous oxidation may alter the amount, composition, and properties of OA much faster than was originally assumed; this could have important implications for OA downwind from sources (e.g., urban centers, forest fires), as well as for the cloud-forming properties of OA.
